references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.B13GRE01USGP: Green, D.M., L.A. Weir, G.S. Casper, and M.J. Lannoo. 2013.  North American Amphibians: Distribution and Diversity.  University of California Press. Berkeley, California. 340 pp.
references.W16NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2016. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://explorer.natureserve.org. (Accessed: March 22, 2016).

references.J12CRO01USGP: Crother, B. I. (ed.) 2012. Standard Common and Current Scientific Names for North American Amphibians, Turtles, Reptiles, and Crocodilians, Seventh Edition. Herpetological Circular 39: 1-92.

habitat_description:
California giant salamanders occur in the Pacific Coastal region surrounding San Francisco Bay north to Mendocino, Napa, and Sonoma counties, but also south into Santa Cruz County. A separate population occurs in Monterey County (Nussbaum 1976). In other words, the range only extends from around Monterey Bay north into Anchor Bay (Green et al. 2013). Elevational range is between near sea level up to 915 meters (Stebbins 2003). During breeding, adults are found under rocks in streams. The habitat of adults and juveniles is associated with semi and permanent streams where adults are encountered under rocks or logs (Petranka 1998). 
Populations have been reportedly lost due to intense human development in their historic range (Green et al. 2013).
